Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: @dukeleto  a couple of things if you are residential that 5c/kWh  is probably supply side only , make sure you add up all the costs (distribution, transmission,  fees etc.)  itâ€™s not too hard to run a 240v circuit run. Need 10 AWG 3 wire .  30A double pole breaker and outlet and PDU with appropriate plug.   The main benefits of running at higher voltage is that you can get more miners in per circuit ( I=V/R). and efficiency increase,  Current generates heat ( W=I ^2*R)  , conductors like copper increase their resistance based on heat resulting in less efficiency.

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Tldr: costs are a little bit higher with electric company with 110v, generates more heat and run less miners per circuit

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @polycryptoblog very good details, thanks. There is a $30/month "service fee" and 5.11 cents/kwh, so yes, my monthly cost approaches 5.11 cents/kwh with more power use, averaging the total cost. It's cheap hydro power from a dam a few miles away ğŸ˜ƒ

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i will definitely add a 240v circuit in the near term, now that I see all the benefits

Author: dukeleto#7326

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Just double pole 30amp is right,  donâ€™t think there is a double pole for 110v because that would be ungrounding the circuit ( cutting it off entirely but could pose a safety hazard if somehow device is energized despite switch being off ) ,  your panel manufacturer should have its recommended breaker.

Content: Double poles are 240v so no worries
